produce.translation[0].definitions[0].de: to cause a particular result or effect
produce.translation[0].definitions[0].ex: New drugs are producing remarkable results.
a rise in sea level produced by climatic change
As a policy, it did not produce the desired effect.
produce.translation[0].definitions[1].de: to make, write etc something to be bought, used, or enjoyed by people
produce.translation[0].definitions[1].ex: The factory produces an incredible 100 cars per hour.
How did you manage to produce a meal so quickly?
produce.translation[0].definitions[2].de: to grow something or make it naturally
produce.translation[0].definitions[2].ex: This region produces the grapes used in champagne.
produce.translation[0].definitions[3].de: if you produce an object, you bring it out or present it, so that people can see or consider it
produce.translation[0].definitions[3].ex: When challenged, he produced a gun.
They were unable to produce any statistics to verify their claims.
produce.translation[0].definitions[4].de: if someone produces a film or play, they find the money for it and control the way it is made
produce.translation[0].definitions[4].ex: Costner produced and directed the film.
produce.translation[0].definitions[5].de: to give birth to a baby or young animals
produce.translation[0].definitions[5].ex: An adult cat may produce kittens three times a year.
produce.translation[1].definitions[0].de: food or other things that have been grown or produced on a farm to be sold
produce.translation[1].definitions[0].no: dairy produce British English (=milk, butter, cheese etc)
produce.translation[1].note_box[0].secti: There is increased demand for organic produce.
The government bought surplus agricultural produce from farmers.
She had filled a basket with her garden produce.
Local produce is used wherever possible.
Wash all fresh produce before use.
Vitamin A can also be obtained from dairy produce and eggs.
produce.translation[2].definitions[0].de: food that has been grown on the land or produced in large quantities, using farming methods
produce.translation[2].definitions[0].ex: Where it once offered 125 items of produce, A&P now sells 300 fruits and vegetables.
produce.translation[3].definitions[0].de: to make or grow something in large quantities to be sold
produce.translation[3].definitions[0].ex: The plant in Leningrad will produce parts used in building construction.
The British assembly plants still don’t produce as efficiently as those in Germany.
Colombia produced a bumper  (=very large) coffee crop this year.
produce.translation[3].definitions[1].de: to make something happen or to have a particular result or effect
produce.translation[3].definitions[1].ex: A strong market could mean sales will produce substantial profit gains.
The planning sessions have not yet produced a coherent strategy.
produce.translation[3].definitions[2].de: to control the preparation of a film, television programme etc, especially the amount of money spent making it
produce.translation[3].definitions[2].ex: Disney’s computer-animated film will be produced by Pixar.
produce.translation[3].definitions[3].de: to show an official document when it is needed, for example as proof of something
produce.translation[3].definitions[3].ex: The judge ordered officials to produce financial records within three days.
